Books and Around Does anybody really know how to talk
to children? I am not sure these talented Michigan
youngsters have the slightest idea whether or not they
are communicating. There is, in this program, the same
elaborate over emphasis done, I presume in the name of
clarity and simplicity. Is it always necessary to discuss
animals, birds and people in tones of awe — is breath¬
lessness essential to understanding in the child’s mind.
Captain Kangaroo just talks to the children and, in my
opinion, his acceptance of them as people, albeit special
little people, is a far more effective way of reaching them
than the method chosen by ’’Books and Around”. My principle
objection is that I feel the show does not communicate fully
..'.I do not necessarily advocate that all children's shows
pattern themselves after the good Captain. No.
Sound Track: Disappointed in this one. The idea is a very
good one but it does not come off for me. The commentator
speaks in a very learned manner but I have the feeling that
he is parroting gibberish compounded of snotty reviews from
the ’’New Yorker” and the defiant but inaccurate memoirs of
Erich Von Stroheim. He goes to a great deal of trouble to
establish points of little consequence — i.e. the similarity
between the voice of Dietrich and Harris. The whole thing
was patchy and condescending. No.
